"Gravitational abyss.<[silence]> Cosmic recycling.<[silence]>
'Black hole' combines 'black' and 'hole.'<[silence]> Black for the darkness they create, and hole for the empty space they seem to occupy.<[silence]> But these aren't ordinary holes—they're regions of space where the gravitational pull is so strong that nothing, not even light, can escape.<[silence]> They form when massive stars die, their cores collapsing under their own weight.<[silence]>

Imagine a star 20 times more massive than our sun, running out of fuel.<[silence]> As it dies, its core collapses, creating a singularity—a point of infinite density where the laws of physics as we know them break down.<[silence]> This is the heart of a black hole, surrounded by an event horizon—the point of no return.<[silence]>

Black holes aren't just cosmic vacuums, though.<[silence]> They interact with their surroundings, sometimes dramatically.<[silence]> When a black hole consumes matter from a nearby star or gas cloud, it creates spectacular fireworks displays called accretion disks.<[silence]> These disks heat up as they spiral inwards, reaching temperatures hot enough to emit X-rays.<[silence]>

Black holes also come in different sizes.<[silence]> Stellar black holes, like the one at the center of our galaxy, have about three times the mass of our sun.<[silence]> Supermassive black holes, found at the hearts of galaxies, can be millions or even billions of times more massive.<[silence]> And then there are miniature black holes, theoretical entities smaller than an atom but with the mass of a mountain.<[silence]>

Despite their fearsome reputation, black holes play a crucial role in the universe.<[silence]> They help shape the evolution of galaxies, and their jets of energy can influence the growth of stars.<[silence]> They're also a key part of the cosmic recycling process, breaking down matter and redistributing it.<[silence]> Three related subjects are how black holes influence galaxy formation, the hunt for miniature black holes here on Earth, and the quest to understand the nature of singularities.<[silence]>"
